titleStmt.title: The letters pattents of the Kings declaration for the referring of the generall assemblie of the princes, cardinals, dukes and peeres as well ecclesiasticall as temporall, the officers of the crowne, the lords, gentlemen, officers and others, vnto the 15. day of March next comming. Also to reclaime his subiects and rebellious townes to his obedience. Published in the Parliament of Caen the 22. of of [sic] December. 1589. Faithfullie translated out of the French copie printed at Caen.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: The Kings Declaration, Importing a Reuocation of all Å¿uch Letters for Ennoblishment, as haue not been verified in the Chamber of accountes of Normandy.
AlÅ¿o of all Å¿uch as haue been graunted to Å¿uch perÅ¿ons as haue or yet do beare armes againÅ¿t his MaieÅ¿tie, and fauour Rebelles.
Together with an ArreÅ¿t or decree of the Court of Parliament of Caen, concerning the reÅ¿idence of Clergie men vpon their Cures, and the warrantiÅ¿e of their Tithes.
Faithfully tranÅ¿lated out of French according to the Coppye printed at Caen.
AT LONDON Printed for Edward White, and are to be Å¿old at the little North door of S. Paules Church, at the Å¿igne of the ãâ¦ã

div.head: The Kings Declaration, importing a rouocation of all Å¿uch Letters for Enno bliÅ¿hment, as haue not been verified in the Chamber of account of Normandy, alÅ¿o of all Å¿uch as haue been graunted to Å¿uch perÅ¿ons as haue or yet doo beare armes againÅ¿t his MaieÅ¿tie, and fauour the Rebels.

opener.signed: HEnry by the grace of God, King of Fraunce and Nauarre,
opener.salute: to our truÅ¿ty and welbeloued, our Officers of accompts, now tranÅ¿ferred to Caen greeting and goodwill.

div.p:
Wheras the late our moÅ¿t honorable Lo. and Brother vpon the neceÅ¿sitie of the affaires of this kingdome, thought good to aduaunce vnto the Å¿tate of Nobilitye, Å¿undrye pezants, Å¿ome for money, others in recompence of their Å¿eruice: the generall Edicts wherof were directed to our Chambers of accounts, to the which eÅ¿pecially the verification of the Å¿aid ennoblishments, alÅ¿o of the money or deÅ¿ert of the gift thereof doth appertaine, and without the which verification which is the proper eÅ¿Å¿ence of the Å¿aid ennoblishments, the Å¿ame are of no force or valew. NotwithÅ¿tanding Å¿ome of our Subiects
in the Å¿aid Court of Normandy, pretending that they haue obtained the Å¿aide Letters of ennoblishment, which they haue not verified before you, do vÅ¿urpe the qualitie & priuilidges of Nobility, and Å¿ome that were Å¿ubiect to tallages, do cauÅ¿e themÅ¿elues to be raced out of the role, to the great preiudice of our treaÅ¿urye, and Å¿uch our Subiectes as doo beare their taxes contrary to all equitye and reaÅ¿on.
AlÅ¿o of thoÅ¿e that haue beene ennobled or haue verrified their Charters after the forme accuÅ¿tomed, Å¿ome haue very ingratefully reuoulted from our Å¿eruice.

We therfore deÅ¿iring for the wealth of our eÅ¿tate, or the releefe of our poore people, to prouide againÅ¿t the fraud and abuÅ¿e committed in the obtaining of the Å¿aide ennoblishments, as well to the detriment of our treaÅ¿urie, as the vnworthineÅ¿Å¿e of thoÅ¿e who by Å¿urpriÅ¿e rebellion or otherwiÅ¿e, haue purchaÅ¿ed the gift therof: and hauing referred the matter to the deliberation of our CounÅ¿ell, by the aduice therof we haue Å¿aid, declared, and ordained, and doo Å¿ay, declare, and
ordain by theÅ¿e preÅ¿ents, that all & euery the Å¿aid ennoblishments heretofore by our Å¿ayd predeceÅ¿Å¿or and vs graunted throughout our Cuntry or Dutchye of Normandy, which yet are not verified in our Å¿aide Chamber of accompts of Normandy to be voide or of none effect. Willing and charging you moÅ¿t expreÅ¿Å¿ely to inhibit and in our name to forbid all purchaÅ¿ers of the Å¿ame, neuer to make any vÅ¿e therof, neither to take or vÅ¿urp the Å¿ayde qualitye or priuiledge of Nobility: alÅ¿o all our Iudges or Officers, not to receiue or tollerate them, vntill they haue been well and duelye verified in our Å¿aid Chamber, vnder pain of tranÅ¿greÅ¿sion of falshood & arbitrary amends albeit there should chaunce to be Å¿ome that haue not been directed therto, which as wreÅ¿ted and not duely verified we haue and do reuoke.

We do moreouer forbid our elect and the Controuler in matter of aide and tallages, euerye one in his election, that they shall not Å¿uffer or permit any of the Å¿aide pretended ennobled PerÅ¿ons, that hath heretofore contributed to our tallages, to be raÅ¿ed out of the
rules of the Å¿ame: alÅ¿o that if any haue been Å¿o blotted out and raced, our pleaÅ¿ure is, that they shall be put in againe and taxed as afore time, vnder paine that themÅ¿elues shall anÅ¿were for it in their own priuate name.

Moreouer to the end to vnderÅ¿tand how they haue done their dueties herein, we doo commaund them to preÅ¿ent vnto you the catalogue and roale of Å¿uch as pretend them Å¿elues to be ennobled in euery election, that at the inÅ¿tance of our Atourney general they maye be aÅ¿signed in our Å¿aide Chamber, to bring in their Letters, which if the caÅ¿e Å¿o fall out shall be retained as being obteined by fraude and contrary to the intent of our predeceÅ¿Å¿or and vs, or els in verrification to taxe them as you shall think reaÅ¿onable.

Futhermore, concerning thoÅ¿e that vngratefullye haue Å¿ince theÅ¿e Nobles reuolted from our Å¿eruice: we haue and doo reuoke all and euery their charters, graunts that haue beene made vnto them, and all verifications that thereof maye haue enÅ¿ued: and as men for their rebellion depriued and diÅ¿graded from all honor and degree of nobility, our will is
that they be Å¿et down and made contributory to our tallages as other Pezants are, or in caÅ¿e they inhabit in the free towns, they shal not take or attribute to theÌÅ¿elues any further Å¿tate or priuiledge then of Pezants, notwithÅ¿tanding whatÅ¿oeuer their Letters of grace, either alreadye or hereafter to be purchaÅ¿ed at our hands, before the Å¿ame haue beene verified in our Å¿aid Chambers of accompts.

We doo alÅ¿o will and commaund you to cauÅ¿e theÅ¿e Letters of declaration to be read, published, regiÅ¿tred, printed and Å¿ent to all our Seas, auditories, and other places conuenient: alÅ¿o to cauÅ¿e the contents in the Å¿ame to be maintained, kept, and obÅ¿erued by Bailifs, Stewards, elect, and others our Officers and Subiects, and to proceed againÅ¿t the infringers thereof by all due and reaÅ¿onable meanes. For this end we giue you full power and authoritie: for Å¿uch is our pleaÅ¿ure.

closer.dateline: Giuen at our Campe at Mante the 29. of Iune, the yeer of grace 1591. and of our raign the 2.

div.p: Signed by the King in his counÅ¿ell Potier, and Å¿ealed with the great Å¿eale vpon a Å¿ingle labell of yellow waxe.

Moreouer vpon the Å¿aide Letters it is written, read, published, and regiÅ¿tred in the Chamber of accounts of Normandy, in the hearing and at the requeÅ¿t of the Kings Attorney Generall in the Å¿ame, like as is conteined in the regiÅ¿ter at Caen the 27. of Iulye in the yeere 1591.

THe Chamber hauing Å¿eene the Letters pattents of the Kings declaration, giuen at his Campe at Mante the 29. of Iune laÅ¿t, containing a reuocation of ennobliÅ¿hments graunted by the Å¿aid Lord and the late King, not verified in the Å¿aid Chamber, vntill the Å¿aide verification in the Å¿ame, albeit there may be Å¿ome whoÅ¿e letters haue not beene directed thereto. AlÅ¿o that concerning Å¿uch as vngratefullye haue reuolted Å¿ince the late troubles: his MaieÅ¿tie hath likewiÅ¿e reuoked their charters and grauntes, together with all the verrifications that may haue enÅ¿ued, and that as men depriued and for their rebellion diÅ¿graded from all honor and degree of nobility: he willeth them to be reduced and Å¿uborned to the tallages as other the Pezants are, or if they inhabite in anye free Townes, they Å¿hall not take vpon them anye other degree or priuelidge theÌ Pezants, notwithÅ¿tanding whatÅ¿oeuer Letters of grace they haue, or heereafter may obtaine of his Å¿aide MaieÅ¿tie, vnleÅ¿Å¿e the firÅ¿t verified in the Å¿aid Chamber, as more at large is conteined in the Å¿aid letters pattents. The Kings
Attorney generall being heard, who hath required the regiÅ¿tring of the Å¿ame, and the whole conÅ¿idered: The Chamber hath ordained and dooth ordaine, that the Å¿aide Letters of declaration of the 29. of Iune laÅ¿t, Å¿halbe read, publiÅ¿hed and regiÅ¿tred in the roules therof. The Vidimus whereof Å¿halbe Å¿ent to the Baylifs and their lieuetenants in euerye Vicounty, alÅ¿o to the elect of the election of this Prouince, that there they may likewiÅ¿e be read and publiÅ¿hed in their Sea and auditories, withall enioyning the Å¿ubÅ¿titutes of the Å¿aid Attorney generall in euery the Å¿aid ivriÅ¿dictions, to aÅ¿siÅ¿t the execution of the Å¿aid Letters, and the Å¿aid lieuetenants of Bailifs and the elect, to Å¿end within one moneth into the Å¿aide Chamber, a roule and catalogue of Å¿uch perÅ¿ons as may haue proÅ¿ecuted their letters of ennobliÅ¿hment before them, or that manifeÅ¿tly haue taken vpon them the Å¿aide title and degree of nobility, Å¿ince the yeere 1574. Together with a Å¿ummary of their behauiours, dealinges and reÅ¿idence: alÅ¿o to Å¿end the coppies of their letters and charters obteined by the Å¿aide ennobled perÅ¿ons and of the arreÅ¿ts of verification thereof enÅ¿uing.
Taken out of the RegeÅ¿ter of the Chamber of accounts of Normandy.

div.head: An ArreÅ¿t or decree of the Courte of Parliament of Caen concerning the reÅ¿idence of Cu rats and Clergie men, vpon their Cures, and the warrantiÅ¿e of their Tythes.

div.p: VPon requeÅ¿t exhibited by the Kings Attorney generall, Å¿hewing that he vnderÅ¿taÌdeth that in diuers places and pariÅ¿hes of this prouince of Normandy, there are riÅ¿en Å¿undrye Souldiours & other vnknown perÅ¿ons in armes, who by plaine force doo endeuour to gather and take vp the tithes of the Å¿aid PariÅ¿hes (malgre thoÅ¿e to whom by right they do appertaine) to the great preiudice of the Clergie, and contrary to the Kings Edicts and decrees: with all requiring the Å¿aid Court to graunt him commiÅ¿sion to enforme againÅ¿t the tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿ors of the Å¿aide Edictes and decrees, as alÅ¿o that the Å¿ame maye be read againe and publiÅ¿hed euen in the Pulpits of the Å¿aid pariÅ¿hes: likewiÅ¿e in the meane time that all men may be inhibited and forbidden not to intrude themÅ¿elues to diÅ¿turb the Å¿aid Clergie, in the receipt of their Å¿aid titles, vnder Å¿uch penalties as by the Å¿aid Court Å¿halbe thought conuenient, naÌely to anÅ¿were all charges, damages and intereÅ¿t of the Å¿aid Clergie and their farmers.

The Court hauing Å¿een the Å¿aid requeÅ¿t, and giuen attendance to the CounÅ¿ellor that made the reporte, all thorowly conÅ¿idered. The Å¿aide Court miniÅ¿tring IuÅ¿tice vpon the peticion of the Å¿ayde Attorney generall, hath ordeined and enioyned all
Curates and EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall perÅ¿ons that haue cure of Soules, to be actually reÅ¿ident vpon their Cures and Benefices, there to preach and teach the word of God, and to inÅ¿truct their PariÅ¿hioners in their due obedience to the King, to pray for his perÅ¿on, with the proÅ¿peritie of his affaires and eÅ¿tate, to obey and fulfil his Edicts and the decrees and arreÅ¿ts of the Å¿aide Courte, vpon the penaltyes in the Å¿ame Å¿et down. And in Å¿o dooing the Å¿aide Court inbibiteth and forbiddeth all perÅ¿ons of whatÅ¿oeuer eÅ¿tate or calling, not to intrude themÅ¿elues directly or indirectly, to moleÅ¿t or hinder the Å¿aid Curates or EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall perÅ¿ons in the enioying of their Cures or benefices, or in the receipt of their Tithes or reuenues of the Å¿ame, vnder paine of confiÅ¿cation of body and goods. And to the end this preÅ¿ent decree may be known to all men, the Å¿aide Courte hath ordained that it Å¿halbe Å¿ent into all the Baylywicks of this reÅ¿ort, withal enioyning the Bailifs, their Lieuetenants, and the Å¿aid Attorney generals Å¿ubÅ¿titutes to cauÅ¿e it to be publiÅ¿hed by Å¿ound of Trumpet in all the accuÅ¿tomed places depending of their iuriÅ¿dictions, namely in the Pulpets at the great parochiall maÅ¿Å¿es in euery ParriÅ¿h, vpon the Sunday and other Å¿olemne feaÅ¿tes, to the end none may be exerciÅ¿ed vpon any pretence of ignorance.

closer.dateline: Giuen at Caen in the Å¿aid Court of Parliament the 7. of AuguÅ¿t. 1591.

div.p: IN the Å¿ame yeere 1591. vpon Monday the 12. of AuguÅ¿t at Caen in the preÅ¿ence of vs Iohn Vauquelin EÅ¿quir, CounÅ¿ellor to the King & Lieutenant Generall to the L. Bayly of Caen, the contents of the areÅ¿t aboue mentioned, was read and publiÅ¿hed in the audience of the iuriÅ¿diction of the Å¿aid Bailiwick and perÅ¿idiall Sea Å¿itting and by vs holden. It was alÅ¿o ordeined at the petition of the kings Attorney generall, that the Å¿ame Å¿halbe alÅ¿o read and publiÅ¿hed with Å¿ound of Trumpet, and common proclamation in all the quarters and places vÅ¿ed for Proclamations in the Å¿aid Town, alÅ¿o that the copies or Vidimus Å¿hall be Å¿ent into all other the Vicountyes of this Bayliwick, there to doo the like: alÅ¿o to all the Curates and Vickers of the pariÅ¿he of this Vicounty, to the end they may read theÌ in the Pulpits of their Å¿ayd pariÅ¿hes vpon the Sondaye, or other Å¿olemne feaÅ¿ts, that none maye pretend cauÅ¿e of ignorance: alÅ¿o that to the Å¿ame ende the Å¿aide arreÅ¿t Å¿hall be printed.

LikewiÅ¿e all Sergeants are enioyned each within his precinct, to Å¿ee to the fulfilling hereof, vnder the penalties Å¿et down therfore to make Å¿uch diÅ¿patch as may be requiÅ¿ite or neceÅ¿Å¿ary therto.

closer.signed: Signed, Vauquelin de la Serre. Criquet.

div.p: THe Å¿ame day and yeer the contents aboue mentioned were read and publiÅ¿hed in the quarters & places accuÅ¿tomed to make proclamations in tnis Towne of Caen, by me Simon Berot Sergeant royall of Caen, in the preÅ¿eÌce of Florimont le Soef ordinary Trompet of the Å¿ame town.
